modules.preparagraph:
Scala tuple combines a fixed number of items together so that they can be passed around as a whole. Unlike an array or list, a tuple can hold objects with different types but they are also immutable. Here is an example of a tuple holding an integer, a string, and the console:

```
val t = (1, "hello", Console)
```

Which is syntactic sugar (short cut) for the following:

```
val t = new Tuple3(1, "hello", Console)
```
As you can see, tuples can be created easily:
modules.code:
val tuple = ("apple", "dog")
val fruit = tuple._1
val animal = tuple._2

fruit should be(__)
animal should be(__)

modules.preparagraph: Tuples may be of mixed type:
modules.code:
val tuple5 = ("a", 1, 2.2, new Date(), BigDecimal(5))

tuple5._2 should be(__)
tuple5._5 should be(__)

modules.preparagraph: Tuples items can be swapped on a Tuple 2
modules.code:
val tuple = ("apple", 3).swap
tuple._1 should be(__)
tuple._2 should be(__)
